Award.AwardTitle: Analytical and Numerical Study of Two Problems Arising in solid-Liquid Interaction
Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the past decades, the study of the motion of a viscous liquid interacting with solid bodies has become one of the main focuses of applied research. Objective of this project is to address two fundamental aspects of solid-liquid interaction directed toward the accomplishment of the following objectives. The first one is devoted to the motion of a rigid body with internal cavities that are completely filled with a viscous liquid. The second one concerns the vibration-induced motion of a rigid body in a viscous liquid. A particularly significant case is when the vibration is induced by a time-periodically displaced mass inside the body.

The interaction of a viscous liquid with a solid body (either rigid or deformable) constitutes a complex and intriguing topic of theoretical and applied research. In fact, not only is it of fundamental theoretical interest, but it also represents the focus of many engineering, biological and medical studies at different scales. Important applications that are immediately related to the present project include, on the one hand, dynamics of flight, space technology, and geophysical problems, and on the other hand, robotic engineering and design of micro- and nano-technological equipment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of the research regarded the study of the motion of the coupled system constituted by a rigid body with an interior cavity completely filled with a viscous (Newtonian) liquid. This study was mostly motivated by a longstanding conjecture formulated back in 1885 by the Russian engineer Nikolai Joukowsky, one of the fathers of modern aerodynamics. Roughly speaking, the conjecture consists in showing that the mechanical stability properties of the rigid body are enormously increased if the cavity is completely filled with a viscous liquid. Even though devices founded upon this conjecture are nowadays currently used -on an entirely "empirical" basis- for instance, to stabilize tall buildings, satellites and shuttles re-entering the Earth's atmosphere, the mathematical analysis at their foundation (the proof of the conjecture, that is) was entirely missing. This fact, in certain circumstances, even led to questioning the validity of the conjecture, mainly in the applied mathematics community. The PI has devoted great effort aimed at investigating the validity of the conjecture, from analytical, numerical and experimental viewpoints. All along the development of the research project, the PI has involved two graduate students (Mr. Mahdi Mohebbi, now Assistant Professor at NYU Stony Brook) and Ms. Giusy Mazzone (currently Research Assistant at Vanderbilt University),  seven undergraduate students and a number of post-doctorate visiting fellows, also partially supported by this grant. In particular, the role of the undergraduate students was to design and implement a device would show evidence of the stabilizing influence of the liquid.  Some of these experiments are posted on YouTube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wXID_yPbla8.

The project has produced  25  papers all with  partial support of this grant. In particular, in an article published in March 2016 on the Archive for Rational Mechanics and Analysis, the PI in collaboration with his junior associates has provided a rigorous proof of the conjecture.

The intellectual merit of the research was to advance the knowledge and understanding in some fundamental aspects of fluid-solid interaction. In addition, the resolution of some questions required completely new methods that could be used to study other problems of mathematical fluid mechanics. Furthermore, and even more importantly, the rigorous mathematical analysis carried out for this project has clarified certain fundamental aspects that have been erroneously addressed in the classical literature.

The broader impact of the researchincluded the training of the female graduate student, Giusy Mazzone, on aspects of solid-liquid interactios from a cross-disciplinary viewpoint, as well as the involvement of several undergraduate students on specific sub-project, mostly of experimental nature. Specifically, Giusy  has acquired her main expertise in the mathematical analysis  but she has also developed breadth in computational and, to an extent, experimental aspects of the discipline. In addition, results related to the project have been disseminated in a number of international conferences, workshops and schools, the latter mostly targeted at post-docs and junior faculty.
